abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Education Project in Pakistan
            was implemented. Frequent changes in personnel adversely
            affected management's efficiency and effectiveness.
            Problems identified in built facilities were caused by some
            design and specification weaknesses which were not detected
            by either the Federal Coordinating Unit (FCU) architect in
            Pakistan or the architect at the Bank during project
            development, and a lack of systematic and effective
            supervision and quality control at critical points by the
            Public Works Department (PWD) in the Punjab, Baluchistan and
            North West Frontier Provinces (NWFP) during the
            implementation of the project. The Government needs to take
            corrective measures regarding under-enrollment in order that
            the expected benefits of the project might be fully
            realized. A few major lessons learned which could improve
            future projects include: (a) the importance of good design
            and clearly written specifications; (b) a clear
            understanding by the Borrower of the total project funds
            available and procedures for requesting withdrawals; (c) the
            need for more effective supervision by the FCU at all sites;
            and (d) the importance of all sites being visited at least
            once by the Bank supervision missions, especially at
            critical point of project implementation.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Education Project will finance
            a project consisting of the following components and related
            technical assistance: (a) Basic Education: (i) the
            construction and equipping of 3 new Teacher Training
            Institutes and the reconstruction, or expansion, and
            equipping of 14 existing Teacher Training Institutes; and
            (ii) phase II of an experimental adult education program and
            a study of supply and demand for female teachers; (b)
            Agricultural and Rural Education: (i) the reconstruction or
            expansion and equipping of 5 existing Agricultural Training
            Institutes; (ii) remodelling and equipping the Sind
            Agricultural University at Tandojam; and (iii) a study on
            training needs for irrigation, water management, and
            irrigated agricultural husbandry and a study on supply and
            demand for middle level agricultural manpower.
